natural problem: Let $S = \{2^0,2^1,2^2,\ldots,2^{10}\}$. Consider all possible positive differences of pairs of elements of $S$. Let $N$ be the sum of all of these differences. Find $N.$
natural solution: When computing $N$, the number $2^x$ will be added $x$ times (for terms $2^x-2^0$, $2^x-2^1$, $\dots,$ $2^x - 2^{x-1}$), and subtracted $10-x$ times.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes S :: "int set" and N :: int
assumes h0 : "S = {2 ^ i | i. 0 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 10}"
and h1 : "N = (\<Sum>x\<in>S. \<Sum>y\<in>S. abs (x - y))"
shows  "N = 16398"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $S = \{2^0,2^1,2^2,\ldots,2^{10}\}$. Consider all possible positive differences of pairs of elements of $S$. Let $N$ be the sum of all of these differences. Find $N.$ The final Answer is 16398
 ### Proof
 When computing $N$, the number $2^x$ will be added $x$ times (for terms $2^x-2^0$, $2^x-2^1$, $\dots,$ $2^x - 2^{x-1}$), and subtracted $10-x$ times.
 Hence, $N$ can be computed as $$N=10\cdot 2^{10} + 8\cdot 2^9 + 6\cdot 2^8 + \cdots - 8\cdot 2^1 - 10\cdot 2^0.$$Then \begin{align} N & = 10(2^{10}-1) + 8(2^9 - 2^1) + 6(2^8-2^2) + 4(2^7-2^3) + 2(2^6-2^4) \\
 & = 10(1023) + 8(510) + 6(252) + 4(120) + 2(48) \\ & = 10(1000+23) + 8(500+10) + 6(250+2) + 480 + 96 \\ &= \boxed{16398}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem 
fixes S :: "int set" and N :: int
assumes h0 : "S = {2 ^ i | i. 0 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 10}"
and h1 : "N = (\<Sum>x\<in>S. \<Sum>y\<in>S. abs (x - y))"
shows  "N = 16398"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Consider the set $S$ of all integers of the form $2^i$ where $0 \le i \le 10$. Let $N$ be the sum of the absolute values of the differences between all pairs of elements in $S$. What is the value of $N$? The final answer is $16398$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes S :: "nat set" and N :: nat
assumes h0 : "S = {2^i | i. 0 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 10}"
and h1 : "N = (\<Sum>x\<in>S. \<Sum>y\<in>S. (if x > y then x - y else 0))"
shows  "N = 16398"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $S = \{2^0,2^1,2^2,\ldots,2^{10}\}$. Consider all possible positive differences of pairs of elements of $S$. Let $N$ be the sum of all of these differences. Find $N.$ The final Answer is 16398
 ### Proof
 When computing $N$, the number $2^x$ will be added $x$ times (for terms $2^x-2^0$, $2^x-2^1$, $\dots,$ $2^x - 2^{x-1}$), and subtracted $10-x$ times.
 Hence, $N$ can be computed as $$N=10\cdot 2^{10} + 8\cdot 2^9 + 6\cdot 2^8 + \cdots - 8\cdot 2^1 - 10\cdot 2^0.$$Then \begin{align} N & = 10(2^{10}-1) + 8(2^9 - 2^1) + 6(2^8-2^2) + 4(2^7-2^3) + 2(2^6-2^4) \\
 & = 10(1023) + 8(510) + 6(252) + 4(120) + 2(48) \\ & = 10(1000+23) + 8(500+10) + 6(250+2) + 480 + 96 \\ &= \boxed{16398}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes S :: "nat set" and N :: nat
assumes h0 : "S = {2^i | i. 0 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 10}"
and h1 : "N = (\<Sum>x\<in>S. \<Sum>y\<in>S. (if x > y then x - y else 0))"
shows  "N = 16398"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Consider a set $S$ consisting of all numbers of the form $2^i$ where $i$ ranges from 0 to 10 inclusive. Let $N$ be the sum of the differences of each pair of distinct elements in $S$ where the larger number is subtracted from the smaller. What is the value of $N$? The final answer is 16398.

theorem
fixes S :: "nat set" and N :: nat

a_2.informal problem: Consider a set $S$ of natural numbers that consists of powers of 2, where the exponent ranges from 0 to 10 inclusive. Calculate the sum of all differences $x - y$ where $x$ and $y$ are elements of $S$ and $x > y$. The final answer is 16398.

fixes S :: "int set" and N :: int
assumes h0 : "S = {2^k | k. 0 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 10}"
and h1 : "N = (\<Sum> a \<in> S. \<Sum> b \<in> S. abs(a - b))"
shows  "N = 16398"
a_3.formal solution:

fixes S :: "int set" and N :: int
assumes h0 : "S = {2 powr k |k. k \<in> {0..10}}"
and h1 : "N = (\<Sum>x\<in>S. \<Sum>y\<in>S. abs (x - y))"
shows  "N = 16398"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes S :: "nat set" and N :: nat
assumes h0 : "S = {2 ^ n |n. n \<in> {0..10}}"
and h1 : "N = (\<Sum>(x,y)\<in>{(i,j). i \<in> S \<and> j \<in> S \<and> i > j}. abs(i - j))"
shows  "N = 16398"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $S = \{2^0,2^1,2^2,\ldots,2^{10}\}$. Consider all possible positive differences of pairs of elements of $S$. Let $N$ be the sum of all of these differences. Find $N.$ The final Answer is 16398
 ### Proof
 When computing $N$, the number $2^x$ will be added $x$ times (for terms $2^x-2^0$, $2^x-2^1$, $\dots,$ $2^x - 2^{x-1}$), and subtracted $10-x$ times.
 Hence, $N$ can be computed as $$N=10\cdot 2^{10} + 8\cdot 2^9 + 6\cdot 2^8 + \cdots - 8\cdot 2^1 - 10\cdot 2^0.$$Then \begin{align} N & = 10(2^{10}-1) + 8(2^9 - 2^1) + 6(2^8-2^2) + 4(2^7-2^3) + 2(2^6-2^4) \\
 & = 10(1023) + 8(510) + 6(252) + 4(120) + 2(48) \\ & = 10(1000+23) + 8(500+10) + 6(250+2) + 480 + 96 \\ &= \boxed{16398}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes S :: "nat set" and N :: nat
assumes h0 : "S = {2 ^ n |n. n \<in> {0..10}}"
and h1 : "N = (\<Sum>(x,y)\<in>{(i,j). i \<in> S \<and> j \<in> S \<and> i > j}. abs(i - j))"
shows  "N = 16398"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: The set S is the set of powers of 2 from $2^0$ to $2^{10}$. What is the sum of the absolute differences between each pair of different elements (i, j) from the set S where i is greater than j? The final answer is 16398.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes S N :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "S = {2^n | n. n \<in> {0..10}}"
and h1 : "N = {abs(a - b) | a b. a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> a > b}"
shows  "sum id N = 16398"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $S = \{2^0,2^1,2^2,\ldots,2^{10}\}$. Consider all possible positive differences of pairs of elements of $S$. Let $N$ be the sum of all of these differences. Find $N.$ The final Answer is 16398
 ### Proof
 When computing $N$, the number $2^x$ will be added $x$ times (for terms $2^x-2^0$, $2^x-2^1$, $\dots,$ $2^x - 2^{x-1}$), and subtracted $10-x$ times.
 Hence, $N$ can be computed as $$N=10\cdot 2^{10} + 8\cdot 2^9 + 6\cdot 2^8 + \cdots - 8\cdot 2^1 - 10\cdot 2^0.$$Then \begin{align} N & = 10(2^{10}-1) + 8(2^9 - 2^1) + 6(2^8-2^2) + 4(2^7-2^3) + 2(2^6-2^4) \\
 & = 10(1023) + 8(510) + 6(252) + 4(120) + 2(48) \\ & = 10(1000+23) + 8(500+10) + 6(250+2) + 480 + 96 \\ &= \boxed{16398}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes S N :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "S = {2^n | n. n \<in> {0..10}}"
and h1 : "N = {abs(a - b) | a b. a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> a > b}"
shows  "sum id N = 16398"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Let $S$ be a set of numbers such that each number is 2 raised to the power of an integer from 0 to 10. Let $N$ be a set of numbers each of which is the absolute difference between any two distinct numbers from the set $S$. What is the sum of all the numbers in the set $N$? The final answer is 16398.
